I never meant any man elſe d'yee ſee, as I am here d'yee ſee, why you know I love my Brother John d'yee ſee, with all my heart d'yee ſee, I only did expreſſe my care of him, being but a young man d'yee ſee, and I knew not how things ſtood d'yee ſee, which it ſeemes you knew better d'yee ſee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. King.
sp.p: Well chuck, what an honour will it be to my Father in his age to have a Prince, or Princeſſe to his Grandchild.

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: How's that ſweet heart?

sp.speaker: Mrs. King.
sp.p: Nay, I ſay no more Windows have eares. Exeunt.

stage.hi: Enter Young Carleton, his Brother George, Madam Moders, and ſeveral others attended upon by Drawers.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: A Wedding and no Muſick.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: They are i'th houſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: Prithee let's have'em; and now moſt gracious Lady as you have given ſpirit to my Clay, and made my ſoul to caper in its Cottage by this bleſt Conjunction; know I'me ſtill your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.p: My Lord I think all Complements ridiculous after this Ceremony. Enter Muſick.

sp.speaker: George Carlet.
sp.p: Come here's a good divertion, what Songs have you?

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: A hundred and fifty, two hundred if need be, I furniſh all the Faires and markets with 'em; I keep a Poet in pay on purpoſe Gentlemen, which is no ſhall charge to me you muſt think, 'tis true the Poet is a prety wit, but what's wit or good lines, nothing, unleſs well Humour'd and well Sung, I ſing 'em all my ſelf, though the lines be never ſo bad I make 'em twang, which ſets off a Poet mainly you know.

sp.speaker: George Carleton.
sp.p: Pox take you for a puppy, leave praiſing your ſelf and let us hear a Song.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: What Song will you have Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Any, any.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: What ſay you to that of the love between a Kitchin Wench and a Chimney Swifter.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: Sirrah d'ye know where you are.

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Sir, I'le fit you with a rare one. Sings.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Hold your howling and behang'd, what a mouth he makes, how he grates the words and tears the ſenſe?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: He's good for nothing; canſt thou tumble?

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: Tumble? I don't underſtand ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: Come, come, a Dance or two, and ſo good Night Mr. Fidler.

sp.speaker: George Carlet.
sp.p: 'Tis pitty to They play, the company dance. keep thee too long from thy happineſs.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: There, are you pleas'd?

sp.speaker: Fidler.
sp.p: Very nobly, we thank your Honour. Exeunt Muſick.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen I muſt crave your pardon, Lady your hand. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A good Night to you Both. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Newes, newes, newes, Boyes.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: What Newes, what newes?

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Wonderfull, ſtrange and true newes, newly Printed and newly come forth.

sp.speaker: 3 Clerk.
sp.p: Of the downfall of Grantham Steeple; the miraculous diſcovery of old Braziel by a Ship-Carpenter at Namptwich, or the horrid murder of Tom Thumb, ſome ſuch paltry ſtuffe.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: You are wide of the matter: Mr. John Carleton is married.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: Prithee to whom?

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: To no leſs then a Princeſs, a German Princeſs believe me.

sp.speaker: 3 Clerk.
sp.p: Why then it muſt be no more Mr. John Carleton, but my Lord John Carleton.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: Pough, I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Thou art an incredulous Coxcomb, I tell thee they keep their Court and State at Durham Houſe 'ith Strand, there you may ſee his Lordſhip if you have a mind to't.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: If I thought he would not take too much State upon him, I'd put my Holy-day Habit on, and take a day to viſit him.

sp.speaker: 3 Clerk.
sp.p: Set thy time and we'l go with thee.

sp.speaker: 2 Clerk.
sp.p: Two dayes hence.

sp.speaker: 1 Clerk.
sp.p: Agree'd, agree'd. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. King, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: What happy Inſtruments have we been Chuck in this buſineſs, they talk of giving hundreds of pounds to others, and I'me ſure we deſerve thouſands.

sp.speaker: Mr. King.
sp.p: That's very rightly ſaid d'ye ſee, but for my part d'ye ſee, I look not for a penny d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Introth Chuck if thou doſt not, I do, there's the ſhort and the long on't, my Father's gone to ſee if ſhe will ſettle her Eſtate upon my Brother John.

sp.speaker: mr. King.
sp.p: And a great deal of reaſon there is in't, d'ye ſee Sweet-heart, for he has been at a vaſt charge d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Her Eſtate will make amends for all, and though he is a falſe Lord now, her Eſtate will make him currant; money will buy Honour at any time Chuck.

sp.speaker: mr. King.
sp.p: I if, it hit right, but there are ſo many cheates abroad d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why I hope thou wavering faith'd man thou doſt not think the Princeſs my Siſter one?

sp.speaker: mr. King.
sp.p:
If ſhe be ſuch a perſon, and have ſuch an Eſtate d'ye ſee, my Brother may bleſs the time he ever ſee us d'ye ſee, but if ſhe be not the perſon and has no Eſtate, why then 'tis a meer cheat d'ye ſee, and we ſhall
ſuffer in our credit cruelly d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Lord help thy ſimple head; I warrant thee man. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Old Carleton, and mr. John Carleton.

sp.speaker: Old Carlet.
sp.p: Unfortunate boy, thou art undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Sir, you do amaze me wonderfully.

sp.speaker: Old Carlet.
sp.p: After thy loſs of time, thy vaſt expences in riotous Banquettings, perpetual Viſits, what haſt thou purchas'd?

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: A reward above my merit Sir; a virtuous Princeſs of high Endowments, and of ample fortunes, rich in her ſelf, her parts ſpeak her a Dowre, ſufficient for a perſon of my quality had ſhe no other Riches to adorne her.

sp.speaker: Old Carlet.
sp.p: A very Puſscat, a ſubtle Carrion, and a curſed cheat.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: With pardon, Sir, I partly do imagine the cauſe of this your ſudden diſcompoſure, you preſt her in my abſence (like a Father) to ſettle her Eſtate on me, which ſhe unwilling to conſent to, hath rais'd this ſtorme within your quiet Boſome.

sp.speaker: Old Carlet.
sp.p: An Eſtate, where lies it? at the Brick-hills, fooliſh boy; ſhe is not worth a groat, but what thou haſt out of thy prodigal affection given her, her Jewels are but counterfeit, and ſhe a baſe impoſture.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: Good Father let not your paſſion ſo deceive your reaſon, ſhe cannot be ſo Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Carlet.
sp.p: Boy, ſhe's a Strumpet, a vagrant, a wandring Baggage that has two Husbands beſide thy ſelf; a paltry Shoomaker is one of them, this I'le make out.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: You have thrown Daggers to my heart Sir.

sp.speaker: Old Carlet.
sp.p: Be not troubl'd Boy, I'le hamper her, I warrant thee, come along with me. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter madam Moders alone.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.p: I do expect a ſtorme, and ſuddenly, by my bad dreames; which tell me I muſt wade through mud and Water; ſignifying troubles dangerous ones: yet I ſhall paſs them all, cleer as a ſheet that has been whiten'd by the whitſters hand.

div.stage: Enter Old Carleton, Young Carleton, Conſtable and others.

sp.speaker: Old Carlet.
sp.p: That's the Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.p: Who do you handle, you unreveren'd Raskalls? why Father, Husband, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Old Carlet.
sp.p: To hang you Whore for having of two Husbands

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.p: Is that all? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Yo. Carlet.
sp.p: Sure ſhe is innocent, her courage ſpeaks her ſo.

sp.speaker: Old Carlet.
sp.p: Away with her Mr. Conſtable. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. King and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. King.
sp.p:
Oh Chuck, Chuck thou haſt defil'd our Neſt, and
thrown a ſpeck upon our Family; the Princeſs is a Whore, a double Whore, ſhe has two Husbands: has your early riſing come to this?

sp.speaker: Mr. King
sp.p: Why honey 'tis true, I took her for a civil Gentlewoman, and ſo I entertain'd her d'ye ſee; now you took her for a Princeſs d'ye ſee, and there is the miſtake d'ye ſee: alas I would not have done ſuch a thing d'ye ſee for a thouſand pound d'ye ſee; nay and more too as poor a man as I am d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: mrs. King.
sp.p: I wiſh it from my heart thou had'ſt been ſick a Bed chuck when thou did'ſt what thou did'ſt; but 'tis no matter, I hope to ſee her hang'd.

sp.speaker: mr. King.
sp.p: Why that will make amends for all d'ye ſee. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter two Gentlemen as from the Seſſions-houſe

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I wiſht I had had your place Sir, you ſat neer the Bench.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Introth I was weary on't, I did not like the Scaene.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: How does the Princeſs carry her ſelf I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I underſtand you not Sir, unleſs you mean a Princeſs that derives her Title from the powdering Tub.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Your pardon Sir, I meane the perſon now is at her Tryal.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: You may aſſure your ſelf ſhe wanted not Confidence, I might ſay impudence.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: They ſay her Husband is a hopefull Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: A ſweet lad, my heart earnes for him; a man well bred of a good Family, and in a hanſome way, thus to be catcht argues a weakneſs ſome where; a groſs overſight; a pituous ſhallow conception.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: How do you think 'twill go with him Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Not with him Sir, 'twill rather go againſt him, the Evidence is A noiſe within. defective:—

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Hark,—I dare ſay ſhe's quit.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: A hard fate has follow'd thee friend Carleton.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I pitty the Gentleman though a ſtranger to me: this buſineſs was not manag'd well I fear, but there's away to bring't about again if ſhe be the ſame perſon.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I believe Enter madam Moders & ſeveral others after her. ſo Sir,—bleſs my eye ſight, here's the beaſt will none ſpit at her, how ſhe ſtares & gloates like old Grimalkin, or mother Gurtons Cat 'ith Colehole.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Is that ſhe Sir?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Yes 'tis ſhe Sir, for want of a better.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Your ſervant Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I'me yours Sir. Exeunt ſeverally.

div.stage: Enter Moders alone, applying her ſelf to the Auditory.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: I've paſt one Tryal; but it is my fear
I ſhall receive a rigid ſentence here;
You think me a bold Cheat, put caſe 'twere ſo,
Which of you are not? now you'd ſwear I know;
But do not leaſt that you deſerve to be
Cenſur'd worſe then you yet can cenſure me.
The Worlds a Cheat, and we that move in it
In our degrees do exerciſe our Wit:
And better 'tis to get a glorious Name
However got; then live by common Fame.
